abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Karnataka
            Community-Based Tank Management Project for India were as
            follows: outcomes were satisfactory; risk to development
            outcome was moderate; Bank performance was satisfactory and
            borrower performance was also satisfactory. Some lessons
            learned includes: community based tank engagement in
            rehabilitation and management can work. The project
            demonstrated the simplified procurement process through
            communities for civil works that may be useful in other
            tanks and other programs. Leadership is required at all
            levels and produces dividends when in place. New models and
            institutional mechanisms need considerable attention to
            start up and scaling up issues and related capacity
            development-with commitment to a longer development process,
            and not rapid scaling up. A commitment to a longer process
            should also limit the pressures for scaling-up too rapidly
            until models are well tested. Managing common property
            resources is highly challenging. Start simple and with tanks
            systems which are likely to be successful. There needs to be
            an institutional support system to continue testing and
            refinements in the model. Monitoring, learning and
            evaluation systems need to be integrated and evolve in a
            concerted manner. Agriculture extension needs farmer to
            farmer interactions.
